&ldquo;If that will be your married look, I, as a Christian, will soon give up the notion of consorting with a mere sprite or salamander.&nbsp; But what had you to ask, thing,&mdash;out with it?&rdquo;

&ldquo;There, you are less than civil now; and I like rudeness a great deal better than flattery.&nbsp; I had rather be a thing than an angel.&nbsp; This is what I have to ask,&mdash;Why did you take such pains to make me believe you wished to marry Miss Ingram?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Is that all?&nbsp; Thank God it is no worse!&rdquo;&nbsp; And now he unknit his black brows; looked down, smiling at me, and stroked my hair, as if well pleased at seeing a danger averted.&nbsp; &ldquo;I think I may confess,&rdquo; he continued, &ldquo;even although I should make you a little indignant, Jane&mdash;and I have seen what a fire-spirit you can be when you are indignant.&nbsp; You glowed in the cool moonlight last night, when you mutinied against fate, and claimed your rank as my equal.&nbsp; Janet, by-the-bye, it was you who made me the offer.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Of course I did.&nbsp; But to the point if you please, sir&mdash;Miss Ingram?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Well, I feigned courtship of Miss Ingram, because I wished to render you as madly in love with me as I was with you; and I knew jealousy would be the best ally I could call in for the furtherance of that end.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Excellent!&nbsp; Now you are small&mdash;not one whit bigger than the end of my little finger.&nbsp; It was a burning shame and a scandalous disgrace to act in that way.&nbsp; Did you think nothing of Miss Ingram&rsquo;s feelings, sir?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Her feelings are concentrated in one&mdash;pride; and that needs humbling.&nbsp; Were you jealous, Jane?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Never mind, Mr. Rochester: it is in no way interesting to you to know that.&nbsp; Answer me truly once more.&nbsp; Do you think Miss Ingram will not suffer from your dishonest coquetry?&nbsp; Won&rsquo;t she feel forsaken and deserted?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Impossible!&mdash;when I told you how she, on the contrary, deserted me: the idea of my insolvency cooled, or rather extinguished, her flame in a moment.&rdquo;

&ldquo;You have a curious, designing mind, Mr. Rochester.&nbsp; I am afraid your principles on some points are eccentric.&rdquo;

&ldquo;My principles were never trained, Jane: they may have grown a little awry for want of attention.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Once again, seriously; may I enjoy the great good that has been vouchsafed to me, without fearing that any one else is suffering the bitter pain I myself felt a while ago?&rdquo;

&ldquo;That you may, my good little girl: there is not another being in the world has the same pure love for me as yourself&mdash;for I lay that pleasant unction to my soul, Jane, a belief in your affection.&rdquo;

I turned my lips to the hand that lay on my shoulder.&nbsp; I loved him very much&mdash;more than I could trust myself to say&mdash;more than words had power to express.

&ldquo;Ask something more,&rdquo; he said presently; &ldquo;it is my delight to be entreated, and to yield.&rdquo;

I was again ready with my request.&nbsp; &ldquo;Communicate your intentions to Mrs. Fairfax, sir: she saw me with you last night in the hall, and she was shocked.&nbsp; Give her some explanation before I see her again.&nbsp; It pains me to be misjudged by so good a woman.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Go to your room, and put on your bonnet,&rdquo; he replied.&nbsp; &ldquo;I mean you to accompany me to Millcote this morning; and while you prepare for the drive, I will enlighten the old lady&rsquo;s understanding.&nbsp; Did she think, Janet, you had given the world for love, and considered it well lost?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I believe she thought I had forgotten my station, and yours, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Station! station!&mdash;your station is in my heart, and on the necks of those who would insult you, now or hereafter.&mdash;Go.&rdquo;

I was soon dressed; and when I heard Mr. Rochester quit Mrs. Fairfax&rsquo;s parlour, I hurried down to it.&nbsp; The old lady, had been reading her morning portion of Scripture&mdash;the Lesson for the day; her Bible lay open before her, and her spectacles were upon it.&nbsp; Her occupation, suspended by Mr. Rochester&rsquo;s announcement, seemed now forgotten: her eyes, fixed on the blank wall opposite, expressed the surprise of a quiet mind stirred by unwonted tidings.&nbsp; Seeing me, she roused herself: she made a sort of effort to smile, and framed a few words of congratulation; but the smile expired, and the sentence was abandoned unfinished.&nbsp; She put up her spectacles, shut the Bible, and pushed her chair back from the table.

&ldquo;I feel so astonished,&rdquo; she began, &ldquo;I hardly know what to say to you, Miss Eyre.&nbsp; I have surely not been dreaming, have I?&nbsp; Sometimes I half fall asleep when I am sitting alone and fancy things that have never happened.&nbsp; It has seemed to me more than once when I have been in a doze, that my dear husband, who died fifteen years since, has come in and sat down beside me; and that I have even heard him call me by my name, Alice, as he used to do.&nbsp; Now, can you tell me whether it is actually true that Mr. Rochester has asked you to marry him?&nbsp; Don&rsquo;t laugh at me.&nbsp; But I really thought he came in here five minutes ago, and said that in a month you would be his wife.&rdquo;

&ldquo;He has said the same thing to me,&rdquo; I replied.

&ldquo;He has!&nbsp; Do you believe him?&nbsp; Have you accepted him?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Yes.&rdquo;

She looked at me bewildered.&nbsp; &ldquo;I could never have thought it.&nbsp; He is a proud man: all the Rochesters were proud: and his father, at least, liked money.&nbsp; He, too, has always been called careful.&nbsp; He means to marry you?&rdquo;

&ldquo;He tells me so.&rdquo;

She surveyed my whole person: in her eyes I read that they had there found no charm powerful enough to solve the enigma.

&ldquo;It passes me!&rdquo; she continued; &ldquo;but no doubt, it is true since you say so.&nbsp; How it will answer, I cannot tell: I really don&rsquo;t know.&nbsp; Equality of position and fortune is often advisable in such cases; and there are twenty years of difference in your ages.&nbsp; He might almost be your father.&rdquo;

&ldquo;No, indeed, Mrs. Fairfax!&rdquo; exclaimed I, nettled; &ldquo;he is nothing like my father!&nbsp; No one, who saw us together, would suppose it for an instant.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester looks as young, and is as young, as some men at five-and-twenty.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Is it really for love he is going to marry you?&rdquo; she asked.

I was so hurt by her coldness and scepticism, that the tears rose to my eyes.

&ldquo;I am sorry to grieve you,&rdquo; pursued the widow; &ldquo;but you are so young, and so little acquainted with men, I wished to put you on your guard.&nbsp; It is an old saying that &lsquo;all is not gold that glitters;&rsquo; and in this case I do fear there will be something found to be different to what either you or I expect.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Why?&mdash;am I a monster?&rdquo; I said: &ldquo;is it impossible that Mr. Rochester should have a sincere affection for me?&rdquo;

&ldquo;No: you are very well; and much improved of late; and Mr. Rochester, I daresay, is fond of you.&nbsp; I have always noticed that you were a sort of pet of his.&nbsp; There are times when, for your sake, I have been a little uneasy at his marked preference, and have wished to put you on your guard: but I did not like to suggest even the possibility of wrong.&nbsp; I knew such an idea would shock, perhaps offend you; and you were so discreet, and so thoroughly modest and sensible, I hoped you might be trusted to protect yourself.&nbsp; Last night I cannot tell you what I suffered when I sought all over the house, and could find you nowhere, nor the master either; and then, at twelve o&rsquo;clock, saw you come in with him.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Well, never mind that now,&rdquo; I interrupted impatiently; &ldquo;it is enough that all was right.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I hope all will be right in the end,&rdquo; she said: &ldquo;but believe me, you cannot be too careful.&nbsp; Try and keep Mr. Rochester at a distance: distrust yourself as well as him.&nbsp; Gentlemen in his station are not accustomed to marry their governesses.&rdquo;

I was growing truly irritated: happily, Ad&egrave;le ran in.

&ldquo;Let me go,&mdash;let me go to Millcote too!&rdquo; she cried.&nbsp; &ldquo;Mr. Rochester won&rsquo;t: though there is so much room in the new carriage.&nbsp; Beg him to let me go mademoiselle.&rdquo;

&ldquo;That I will, Ad&egrave;le;&rdquo; and I hastened away with her, glad to quit my gloomy monitress.&nbsp; The carriage was ready: they were bringing it round to the front, and my master was pacing the pavement, Pilot following him backwards and forwards.

&ldquo;Ad&egrave;le may accompany us, may she not, sir?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I told her no.&nbsp; I&rsquo;ll have no brats!&mdash;I&rsquo;ll have only you.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Do let her go, Mr. Rochester, if you please: it would be better.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Not it: she will be a restraint.&rdquo;

He was quite peremptory, both in look and voice.&nbsp; The chill of Mrs. Fairfax&rsquo;s warnings, and the damp of her doubts were upon me: something of unsubstantiality and uncertainty had beset my hopes.&nbsp; I half lost the sense of power over him.&nbsp; I was about mechanically to obey him, without further remonstrance; but as he helped me into the carriage, he looked at my face.

&ldquo;What is the matter?&rdquo; he asked; &ldquo;all the sunshine is gone.&nbsp; Do you really wish the bairn to go?&nbsp; Will it annoy you if she is left behind?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I would far rather she went, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Then off for your bonnet, and back like a flash of lightning!&rdquo; cried he to Ad&egrave;le.

She obeyed him with what speed she might.

&ldquo;After all, a single morning&rsquo;s interruption will not matter much,&rdquo; said he, &ldquo;when I mean shortly to claim you&mdash;your thoughts, conversation, and company&mdash;for life.&rdquo;

Ad&egrave;le, when lifted in, commenced kissing me, by way of expressing her gratitude for my intercession: she was instantly stowed away into a corner on the other side of him.&nbsp; She then peeped round to where I sat; so stern a neighbour was too restrictive to him, in his present fractious mood, she dared whisper no observations, nor ask of him any information.

&ldquo;Let her come to me,&rdquo; I entreated: &ldquo;she will, perhaps, trouble you, sir: there is plenty of room on this side.&rdquo;

He handed her over as if she had been a lapdog.&nbsp; &ldquo;I&rsquo;ll send her to school yet,&rdquo; he said, but now he was smiling.

Ad&egrave;le heard him, and asked if she was to go to school &ldquo;sans mademoiselle?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Yes,&rdquo; he replied, &ldquo;absolutely sans mademoiselle; for I am to take mademoiselle to the moon, and there I shall seek a cave in one of the white valleys among the volcano-tops, and mademoiselle shall live with me there, and only me.&rdquo;

&ldquo;She will have nothing to eat: you will starve her,&rdquo; observed Ad&egrave;le.

&ldquo;I shall gather manna for her morning and night: the plains and hillsides in the moon are bleached with manna, Ad&egrave;le.&rdquo;

&ldquo;She will want to warm herself: what will she do for a fire?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Fire rises out of the lunar mountains: when she is cold, I&rsquo;ll carry her up to a peak, and lay her down on the edge of a crater.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Oh, qu&rsquo; elle y sera mal&mdash;peu comfortable!&nbsp; And her clothes, they will wear out: how can she get new ones?&rdquo;

Mr. Rochester professed to be puzzled.&nbsp; &ldquo;Hem!&rdquo; said he.&nbsp; &ldquo;What would you do, Ad&egrave;le?&nbsp; Cudgel your brains for an expedient.&nbsp; How would a white or a pink cloud answer for a gown, do you think?&nbsp; And one could cut a pretty enough scarf out of a rainbow.&rdquo;

&ldquo;She is far better as she is,&rdquo; concluded Ad&egrave;le, after musing some time: &ldquo;besides, she would get tired of living with only you in the moon.&nbsp; If I were mademoiselle, I would never consent to go with you.&rdquo;

&ldquo;She has consented: she has pledged her word.&rdquo;

&ldquo;But you can&rsquo;t get her there; there is no road to the moon: it is all air; and neither you nor she can fly.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Ad&egrave;le, look at that field.&rdquo;&nbsp; We were now outside Thornfield gates, and bowling lightly along the smooth road to Millcote, where the dust was well laid by the thunderstorm, and, where the low hedges and lofty timber trees on each side glistened green and rain-refreshed.

&ldquo;In that field, Ad&egrave;le, I was walking late one evening about a fortnight since&mdash;the evening of the day you helped me to make hay in the orchard meadows; and, as I was tired with raking swaths, I sat down to rest me on a stile; and there I took out a little book and a pencil, and began to write about a misfortune that befell me long ago, and a wish I had for happy days to come: I was writing away very fast, though daylight was fading from the leaf, when something came up the path and stopped two yards off me.&nbsp; I looked at it.&nbsp; It was a little thing with a veil of gossamer on its head.&nbsp; I beckoned it to come near me; it stood soon at my knee.&nbsp; I never spoke to it, and it never spoke to me, in words; but I read its eyes, and it read mine; and our speechless colloquy was to this effect&mdash;

&ldquo;It was a fairy, and come from Elf-land, it said; and its errand was to make me happy: I must go with it out of the common world to a lonely place&mdash;such as the moon, for instance&mdash;and it nodded its head towards her horn, rising over Hay-hill: it told me of the alabaster cave and silver vale where we might live.&nbsp; I said I should like to go; but reminded it, as you did me, that I had no wings to fly.

&ldquo;&lsquo;Oh,&rsquo; returned the fairy, &lsquo;that does not signify!&nbsp; Here is a talisman will remove all difficulties;&rsquo; and she held out a pretty gold ring.&nbsp; &lsquo;Put it,&rsquo; she said, &lsquo;on the fourth finger of my left hand, and I am yours, and you are mine; and we shall leave earth, and make our own heaven yonder.&rsquo;&nbsp; She nodded again at the moon.&nbsp; The ring, Ad&egrave;le, is in my breeches-pocket, under the disguise of a sovereign: but I mean soon to change it to a ring again.&rdquo;

&ldquo;But what has mademoiselle to do with it?&nbsp; I don&rsquo;t care for the fairy: you said it was mademoiselle you would take to the moon?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Mademoiselle is a fairy,&rdquo; he said, whispering mysteriously.&nbsp; Whereupon I told her not to mind his badinage; and she, on her part, evinced a fund of genuine French scepticism: denominating Mr. Rochester &ldquo;un vrai menteur,&rdquo; and assuring him that she made no account whatever of his &ldquo;contes de f&eacute;e,&rdquo; and that &ldquo;du reste, il n&rsquo;y avait pas de f&eacute;es, et quand m&ecirc;me il y en avait:&rdquo; she was sure they would never appear to him, nor ever give him rings, or offer to live with him in the moon.

The hour spent at Millcote was a somewhat harassing one to me.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester obliged me to go to a certain silk warehouse: there I was ordered to choose half-a-dozen dresses.&nbsp; I hated the business, I begged leave to defer it: no&mdash;it should be gone through with now.&nbsp; By dint of entreaties expressed in energetic whispers, I reduced the half-dozen to two: these however, he vowed he would select himself.&nbsp; With anxiety I watched his eye rove over the gay stores: he fixed on a rich silk of the most brilliant amethyst dye, and a superb pink satin.&nbsp; I told him in a new series of whispers, that he might as well buy me a gold gown and a silver bonnet at once: I should certainly never venture to wear his choice.&nbsp; With infinite difficulty, for he was stubborn as a stone, I persuaded him to make an exchange in favour of a sober black satin and pearl-grey silk.&nbsp; &ldquo;It might pass for the present,&rdquo; he said; &ldquo;but he would yet see me glittering like a parterre.&rdquo;

Glad was I to get him out of the silk warehouse, and then out of a jewellers shop: the more he bought me, the more my cheek burned with a sense of annoyance and degradation.&nbsp; As we re-entered the carriage, and I sat back feverish and fagged, I remembered what, in the hurry of events, dark and bright, I had wholly forgotten&mdash;the letter of my uncle, John Eyre, to Mrs. Reed: his intention to adopt me and make me his legatee.&nbsp; &ldquo;It would, indeed, be a relief,&rdquo; I thought, &ldquo;if I had ever so small an independency; I never can bear being dressed like a doll by Mr. Rochester, or sitting like a second Danae with the golden shower falling daily round me.&nbsp; I will write to Madeira the moment I get home, and tell my uncle John I am going to be married, and to whom: if I had but a prospect of one day bringing Mr. Rochester an accession of fortune, I could better endure to be kept by him now.&rdquo;&nbsp; And somewhat relieved by this idea (which I failed not to execute that day), I ventured once more to meet my master&rsquo;s and lover&rsquo;s eye, which most pertinaciously sought mine, though I averted both face and gaze.&nbsp; He smiled; and I thought his smile was such as a sultan might, in a blissful and fond moment, bestow on a slave his gold and gems had enriched: I crushed his hand, which was ever hunting mine, vigorously, and thrust it back to him red with the passionate pressure.

&ldquo;You need not look in that way,&rdquo; I said; &ldquo;if you do, I&rsquo;ll wear nothing but my old Lowood frocks to the end of the chapter.&nbsp; I&rsquo;ll be married in this lilac gingham: you may make a dressing-gown for yourself out of the pearl-grey silk, and an infinite series of waistcoats out of the black satin.&rdquo;

He chuckled; he rubbed his hands.&nbsp; &ldquo;Oh, it is rich to see and hear her?&rdquo; he exclaimed.&nbsp; &ldquo;Is she original?&nbsp; Is she piquant?&nbsp; I would not exchange this one little English girl for the Grand Turk&rsquo;s whole seraglio, gazelle-eyes, houri forms, and all!&rdquo;

The Eastern allusion bit me again.&nbsp; &ldquo;I&rsquo;ll not stand you an inch in the stead of a seraglio,&rdquo; I said; &ldquo;so don&rsquo;t consider me an equivalent for one.&nbsp; If you have a fancy for anything in that line, away with you, sir, to the bazaars of Stamboul without delay, and lay out in extensive slave-purchases some of that spare cash you seem at a loss to spend satisfactorily here.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And what will you do, Janet, while I am bargaining for so many tons of flesh and such an assortment of black eyes?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I&rsquo;ll be preparing myself to go out as a missionary to preach liberty to them that are enslaved&mdash;your harem inmates amongst the rest.&nbsp; I&rsquo;ll get admitted there, and I&rsquo;ll stir up mutiny; and you, three-tailed bashaw as you are, sir, shall in a trice find yourself fettered amongst our hands: nor will I, for one, consent to cut your bonds till you have signed a charter, the most liberal that despot ever yet conferred.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I would consent to be at your mercy, Jane.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I would have no mercy, Mr. Rochester, if you supplicated for it with an eye like that.&nbsp; While you looked so, I should be certain that whatever charter you might grant under coercion, your first act, when released, would be to violate its conditions.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Why, Jane, what would you have?&nbsp; I fear you will compel me to go through a private marriage ceremony, besides that performed at the altar.&nbsp; You will stipulate, I see, for peculiar terms&mdash;what will they be?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I only want an easy mind, sir; not crushed by crowded obligations.&nbsp; Do you remember what you said of C&eacute;line Varens?&mdash;of the diamonds, the cashmeres you gave her?&nbsp; I will not be your English C&eacute;line Varens.&nbsp; I shall continue to act as Ad&egrave;le&rsquo;s governess; by that I shall earn my board and lodging, and thirty pounds a year besides.&nbsp; I&rsquo;ll furnish my own wardrobe out of that money, and you shall give me nothing but&mdash;&rdquo;

&ldquo;Well, but what?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Your regard; and if I give you mine in return, that debt will be quit.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Well, for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, you haven&rsquo;t your equal,&rdquo; said he.&nbsp; We were now approaching Thornfield.&nbsp; &ldquo;Will it please you to dine with me to-day?&rdquo; he asked, as we re-entered the gates.

&ldquo;No, thank you, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And what for, &lsquo;no, thank you?&rsquo; if one may inquire.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I never have dined with you, sir: and I see no reason why I should now: till&mdash;&rdquo;

&ldquo;Till what?&nbsp; You delight in half-phrases.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Till I can&rsquo;t help it.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Do you suppose I eat like an ogre or a ghoul, that you dread being the companion of my repast?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I have formed no supposition on the subject, sir; but I want to go on as usual for another month.&rdquo;

&ldquo;You will give up your governessing slavery at once.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Indeed, begging your pardon, sir, I shall not.&nbsp; I shall just go on with it as usual.&nbsp; I shall keep out of your way all day, as I have been accustomed to do: you may send for me in the evening, when you feel disposed to see me, and I&rsquo;ll come then; but at no other time.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I want a smoke, Jane, or a pinch of snuff, to comfort me under all this, &lsquo;pour me donner une contenance,&rsquo; as Ad&egrave;le would say; and unfortunately I have neither my cigar-case, nor my snuff-box.&nbsp; But listen&mdash;whisper.&nbsp; It is your time now, little tyrant, but it will be mine presently; and when once I have fairly seized you, to have and to hold, I&rsquo;ll just&mdash;figuratively speaking&mdash;attach you to a chain like this&rdquo; (touching his watch-guard).&nbsp; &ldquo;Yes, bonny wee thing, I&rsquo;ll wear you in my bosom, lest my jewel I should tyne.&rdquo;

He said this as he helped me to alight from the carriage, and while he afterwards lifted out Ad&egrave;le, I entered the house, and made good my retreat upstairs.

He duly summoned me to his presence in the evening.&nbsp; I had prepared an occupation for him; for I was determined not to spend the whole time in a t&ecirc;te-&agrave;-t&ecirc;te conversation.&nbsp; I remembered his fine voice; I knew he liked to sing&mdash;good singers generally do.&nbsp; I was no vocalist myself, and, in his fastidious judgment, no musician, either; but I delighted in listening when the performance was good.&nbsp; No sooner had twilight, that hour of romance, began to lower her blue and starry banner over the lattice, than I rose, opened the piano, and entreated him, for the love of heaven, to give me a song.&nbsp; He said I was a capricious witch, and that he would rather sing another time; but I averred that no time was like the present.

&ldquo;Did I like his voice?&rdquo; he asked.

&ldquo;Very much.&rdquo;&nbsp; I was not fond of pampering that susceptible vanity of his; but for once, and from motives of expediency, I would e&rsquo;en soothe and stimulate it.

&ldquo;Then, Jane, you must play the accompaniment.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Very well, sir, I will try.&rdquo;

I did try, but was presently swept off the stool and denominated &ldquo;a little bungler.&rdquo;&nbsp; Being pushed unceremoniously to one side&mdash;which was precisely what I wished&mdash;he usurped my place, and proceeded to accompany himself: for he could play as well as sing.&nbsp; I hied me to the window-recess.&nbsp; And while I sat there and looked out on the still trees and dim lawn, to a sweet air was sung in mellow tones the following strain:&mdash;

&ldquo;The truest love that ever heart &nbsp;&nbsp; Felt at its kindled core, Did through each vein, in quickened start, &nbsp;&nbsp; The tide of being pour.

Her coming was my hope each day, &nbsp;&nbsp; Her parting was my pain; The chance that did her steps delay &nbsp;&nbsp; Was ice in every vein.

I dreamed it would be nameless bliss, &nbsp;&nbsp; As I loved, loved to be; And to this object did I press &nbsp;&nbsp; As blind as eagerly.

But wide as pathless was the space &nbsp;&nbsp; That lay our lives between, And dangerous as the foamy race &nbsp;&nbsp; Of ocean-surges green.

And haunted as a robber-path &nbsp;&nbsp; Through wilderness or wood; For Might and Right, and Woe and Wrath, &nbsp;&nbsp; Between our spirits stood.

I dangers dared; I hindrance scorned; &nbsp;&nbsp; I omens did defy: Whatever menaced, harassed, warned, &nbsp;&nbsp; I passed impetuous by.

On sped my rainbow, fast as light; &nbsp;&nbsp; I flew as in a dream; For glorious rose upon my sight &nbsp;&nbsp; That child of Shower and Gleam.

Still bright on clouds of suffering dim &nbsp;&nbsp; Shines that soft, solemn joy; Nor care I now, how dense and grim &nbsp;&nbsp; Disasters gather nigh.

I care not in this moment sweet, &nbsp;&nbsp; Though all I have rushed o&rsquo;er Should come on pinion, strong and fleet, &nbsp;&nbsp; Proclaiming vengeance sore:

Though haughty Hate should strike me down, &nbsp;&nbsp; Right, bar approach to me, And grinding Might, with furious frown, &nbsp;&nbsp; Swear endless enmity.

My love has placed her little hand &nbsp;&nbsp; With noble faith in mine, And vowed that wedlock&rsquo;s sacred band &nbsp;&nbsp; Our nature shall entwine.

My love has sworn, with sealing kiss, &nbsp;&nbsp; With me to live&mdash;to die; I have at last my nameless bliss. &nbsp;&nbsp; As I love&mdash;loved am I!&rdquo;

He rose and came towards me, and I saw his face all kindled, and his full falcon-eye flashing, and tenderness and passion in every lineament.&nbsp; I quailed momentarily&mdash;then I rallied.&nbsp; Soft scene, daring demonstration, I would not have; and I stood in peril of both: a weapon of defence must be prepared&mdash;I whetted my tongue: as he reached me, I asked with asperity, &ldquo;whom he was going to marry now?&rdquo;

&ldquo;That was a strange question to be put by his darling Jane.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Indeed!&nbsp; I considered it a very natural and necessary one: he had talked of his future wife dying with him.&nbsp; What did he mean by such a pagan idea?&nbsp; I had no intention of dying with him&mdash;he might depend on that.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Oh, all he longed, all he prayed for, was that I might live with him!&nbsp; Death was not for such as I.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Indeed it was: I had as good a right to die when my time came as he had: but I should bide that time, and not be hurried away in a suttee.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Would I forgive him for the selfish idea, and prove my pardon by a reconciling kiss?&rdquo;

&ldquo;No: I would rather be excused.&rdquo;

Here I heard myself apostrophised as a &ldquo;hard little thing;&rdquo; and it was added, &ldquo;any other woman would have been melted to marrow at hearing such stanzas crooned in her praise.&rdquo;

I assured him I was naturally hard&mdash;very flinty, and that he would often find me so; and that, moreover, I was determined to show him divers rugged points in my character before the ensuing four weeks elapsed: he should know fully what sort of a bargain he had made, while there was yet time to rescind it.

&ldquo;Would I be quiet and talk rationally?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I would be quiet if he liked, and as to talking rationally, I flattered myself I was doing that now.&rdquo;

He fretted, pished, and pshawed.&nbsp; &ldquo;Very good,&rdquo; I thought; &ldquo;you may fume and fidget as you please: but this is the best plan to pursue with you, I am certain.&nbsp; I like you more than I can say; but I&rsquo;ll not sink into a bathos of sentiment: and with this needle of repartee I&rsquo;ll keep you from the edge of the gulf too; and, moreover, maintain by its pungent aid that distance between you and myself most conducive to our real mutual advantage.&rdquo;

From less to more, I worked him up to considerable irritation; then, after he had retired, in dudgeon, quite to the other end of the room, I got up, and saying, &ldquo;I wish you good-night, sir,&rdquo; in my natural and wonted respectful manner, I slipped out by the side-door and got away.

The system thus entered on, I pursued during the whole season of probation; and with the best success.&nbsp; He was kept, to be sure, rather cross and crusty; but on the whole I could see he was excellently entertained, and that a lamb-like submission and turtle-dove sensibility, while fostering his despotism more, would have pleased his judgment, satisfied his common-sense, and even suited his taste less.

In other people&rsquo;s presence I was, as formerly, deferential and quiet; any other line of conduct being uncalled for: it was only in the evening conferences I thus thwarted and afflicted him.&nbsp; He continued to send for me punctually the moment the clock struck seven; though when I appeared before him now, he had no such honeyed terms as &ldquo;love&rdquo; and &ldquo;darling&rdquo; on his lips: the best words at my service were &ldquo;provoking puppet,&rdquo; &ldquo;malicious elf,&rdquo; &ldquo;sprite,&rdquo; &ldquo;changeling,&rdquo; &c.&nbsp; For caresses, too, I now got grimaces; for a pressure of the hand, a pinch on the arm; for a kiss on the cheek, a severe tweak of the ear.&nbsp; It was all right: at present I decidedly preferred these fierce favours to anything more tender.&nbsp; Mrs. Fairfax, I saw, approved me: her anxiety on my account vanished; therefore I was certain I did well.&nbsp; Meantime, Mr. Rochester affirmed I was wearing him to skin and bone, and threatened awful vengeance for my present conduct at some period fast coming.&nbsp; I laughed in my sleeve at his menaces.&nbsp; &ldquo;I can keep you in reasonable check now,&rdquo; I reflected; &ldquo;and I don&rsquo;t doubt to be able to do it hereafter: if one expedient loses its virtue, another must be devised.&rdquo;

Yet after all my task was not an easy one; often I would rather have pleased than teased him.&nbsp; My future husband was becoming to me my whole world; and more than the world: almost my hope of heaven.&nbsp; He stood between me and every thought of religion, as an eclipse intervenes between man and the broad sun.&nbsp; I could not, in those days, see God for His creature: of whom I had made an idol.

CHAPTER XXV

The month of courtship had wasted: its very last hours were being numbered.&nbsp; There was no putting off the day that advanced&mdash;the bridal day; and all preparations for its arrival were complete.&nbsp; I, at least, had nothing more to do: there were my trunks, packed, locked, corded, ranged in a row along the wall of my little chamber; to-morrow, at this time, they would be far on their road to London: and so should I (D.V.),&mdash;or rather, not I, but one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not.&nbsp; The cards of address alone remained to nail on: they lay, four little squares, in the drawer.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester had himself written the direction, &ldquo;Mrs. Rochester, --- Hotel, London,&rdquo; on each: I could not persuade myself to affix them, or to have them affixed.&nbsp; Mrs. Rochester!&nbsp; She did not exist: she would not be born till to-morrow, some time after eight o&rsquo;clock a.m.; and I would wait to be assured she had come into the world alive before I assigned to her all that property.&nbsp; It was enough that in yonder closet, opposite my dressing-table, garments said to be hers had already displaced my black stuff Lowood frock and straw bonnet: for not to me appertained that suit of wedding raiment; the pearl-coloured robe, the vapoury veil pendent from the usurped portmanteau.&nbsp; I shut the closet to conceal the strange, wraith-like apparel it contained; which, at this evening hour&mdash;nine o&rsquo;clock&mdash;gave out certainly a most ghostly shimmer through the shadow of my apartment.&nbsp; &ldquo;I will leave you by yourself, white dream,&rdquo; I said.&nbsp; &ldquo;I am feverish: I hear the wind blowing: I will go out of doors and feel it.&rdquo;

It was not only the hurry of preparation that made me feverish; not only the anticipation of the great change&mdash;the new life which was to commence to-morrow: both these circumstances had their share, doubtless, in producing that restless, excited mood which hurried me forth at this late hour into the darkening grounds: but a third cause influenced my mind more than they.

I had at heart a strange and anxious thought.&nbsp; Something had happened which I could not comprehend; no one knew of or had seen the event but myself: it had taken place the preceding night.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester that night was absent from home; nor was he yet returned: business had called him to a small estate of two or three farms he possessed thirty miles off&mdash;business it was requisite he should settle in person, previous to his meditated departure from England.&nbsp; I waited now his return; eager to disburthen my mind, and to seek of him the solution of the enigma that perplexed me.&nbsp; Stay till he comes, reader; and, when I disclose my secret to him, you shall share the confidence.

I sought the orchard, driven to its shelter by the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain.&nbsp; Instead of subsiding as night drew on, it seemed to augment its rush and deepen its roar: the trees blew steadfastly one way, never writhing round, and scarcely tossing back their boughs once in an hour; so continuous was the strain bending their branchy heads northward&mdash;the clouds drifted from pole to pole, fast following, mass on mass: no glimpse of blue sky had been visible that July day.

It was not without a certain wild pleasure I ran before the wind, delivering my trouble of mind to the measureless air-torrent thundering through space.&nbsp; Descending the laurel walk, I faced the wreck of the chestnut-tree; it stood up black and riven: the trunk, split down the centre, gasped ghastly.&nbsp; The cloven halves were not broken from each other, for the firm base and strong roots kept them unsundered below; though community of vitality was destroyed&mdash;the sap could flow no more: their great boughs on each side were dead, and next winter&rsquo;s tempests would be sure to fell one or both to earth: as yet, however, they might be said to form one tree&mdash;a ruin, but an entire ruin.

&ldquo;You did right to hold fast to each other,&rdquo; I said: as if the monster-splinters were living things, and could hear me.&nbsp; &ldquo;I think, scathed as you look, and charred and scorched, there must be a little sense of life in you yet, rising out of that adhesion at the faithful, honest roots: you will never have green leaves more&mdash;never more see birds making nests and singing idyls in your boughs; the time of pleasure and love is over with you: but you are not desolate: each of you has a comrade to sympathise with him in his decay.&rdquo;&nbsp; As I looked up at them, the moon appeared momentarily in that part of the sky which filled their fissure; her disk was blood-red and half overcast; she seemed to throw on me one bewildered, dreary glance, and buried herself again instantly in the deep drift of cloud.&nbsp; The wind fell, for a second, round Thornfield; but far away over wood and water, poured a wild, melancholy wail: it was sad to listen to, and I ran off again.

Here and there I strayed through the orchard, gathered up the apples with which the grass round the tree roots was thickly strewn; then I employed myself in dividing the ripe from the unripe; I carried them into the house and put them away in the store-room.&nbsp; Then I repaired to the library to ascertain whether the fire was lit, for, though summer, I knew on such a gloomy evening Mr. Rochester would like to see a cheerful hearth when he came in: yes, the fire had been kindled some time, and burnt well.&nbsp; I placed his arm-chair by the chimney-corner: I wheeled the table near it: I let down the curtain, and had the candles brought in ready for lighting.&nbsp; More restless than ever, when I had completed these arrangements I could not sit still, nor even remain in the house: a little time-piece in the room and the old clock in the hall simultaneously struck ten.

&ldquo;How late it grows!&rdquo; I said.&nbsp; &ldquo;I will run down to the gates: it is moonlight at intervals; I can see a good way on the road.&nbsp; He may be coming now, and to meet him will save some minutes of suspense.&rdquo;

The wind roared high in the great trees which embowered the gates; but the road as far as I could see, to the right hand and the left, was all still and solitary: save for the shadows of clouds crossing it at intervals as the moon looked out, it was but a long pale line, unvaried by one moving speck.

A puerile tear dimmed my eye while I looked&mdash;a tear of disappointment and impatience; ashamed of it, I wiped it away.&nbsp; I lingered; the moon shut herself wholly within her chamber, and drew close her curtain of dense cloud: the night grew dark; rain came driving fast on the gale.

&ldquo;I wish he would come!&nbsp; I wish he would come!&rdquo; I exclaimed, seized with hypochondriac foreboding.&nbsp; I had expected his arrival before tea; now it was dark: what could keep him?&nbsp; Had an accident happened?&nbsp; The event of last night again recurred to me.&nbsp; I interpreted it as a warning of disaster.&nbsp; I feared my hopes were too bright to be realised; and I had enjoyed so much bliss lately that I imagined my fortune had passed its meridian, and must now decline.

&ldquo;Well, I cannot return to the house,&rdquo; I thought; &ldquo;I cannot sit by the fireside, while he is abroad in inclement weather: better tire my limbs than strain my heart; I will go forward and meet him.&rdquo;

I set out; I walked fast, but not far: ere I had measured a quarter of a mile, I heard the tramp of hoofs; a horseman came on, full gallop; a dog ran by his side.&nbsp; Away with evil presentiment!&nbsp; It was he: here he was, mounted on Mesrour, followed by Pilot.&nbsp; He saw me; for the moon had opened a blue field in the sky, and rode in it watery bright: he took his hat off, and waved it round his head.&nbsp; I now ran to meet him.

&ldquo;There!&rdquo; he exclaimed, as he stretched out his hand and bent from the saddle: &ldquo;You can&rsquo;t do without me, that is evident.&nbsp; Step on my boot-toe; give me both hands: mount!&rdquo;

I obeyed: joy made me agile: I sprang up before him.&nbsp; A hearty kissing I got for a welcome, and some boastful triumph, which I swallowed as well as I could.&nbsp; He checked himself in his exultation to demand, &ldquo;But is there anything the matter, Janet, that you come to meet me at such an hour?&nbsp; Is there anything wrong?&rdquo;

&ldquo;No, but I thought you would never come.&nbsp; I could not bear to wait in the house for you, especially with this rain and wind.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Rain and wind, indeed!&nbsp; Yes, you are dripping like a mermaid; pull my cloak round you: but I think you are feverish, Jane: both your cheek and hand are burning hot.&nbsp; I ask again, is there anything the matter?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Nothing now; I am neither afraid nor unhappy.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Then you have been both?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Rather: but I&rsquo;ll tell you all about it by-and-bye, sir; and I daresay you will only laugh at me for my pains.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I&rsquo;ll laugh at you heartily when to-morrow is past; till then I dare not: my prize is not certain.&nbsp; This is you, who have been as slippery as an eel this last month, and as thorny as a briar-rose?&nbsp; I could not lay a finger anywhere but I was pricked; and now I seem to have gathered up a stray lamb in my arms.&nbsp; You wandered out of the fold to seek your shepherd, did you, Jane?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I wanted you: but don&rsquo;t boast.&nbsp; Here we are at Thornfield: now let me get down.&rdquo;

He landed me on the pavement.&nbsp; As John took his horse, and he followed me into the hall, he told me to make haste and put something dry on, and then return to him in the library; and he stopped me, as I made for the staircase, to extort a promise that I would not be long: nor was I long; in five minutes I rejoined him.&nbsp; I found him at supper.

&ldquo;Take a seat and bear me company, Jane: please God, it is the last meal but one you will eat at Thornfield Hall for a long time.&rdquo;

I sat down near him, but told him I could not eat.&nbsp; &ldquo;Is it because you have the prospect of a journey before you, Jane?&nbsp; Is it the thoughts of going to London that takes away your appetite?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I cannot see my prospects clearly to-night, sir; and I hardly know what thoughts I have in my head.&nbsp; Everything in life seems unreal.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Except me: I am substantial enough&mdash;touch me.&rdquo;

&ldquo;You, sir, are the most phantom-like of all: you are a mere dream.&rdquo;

He held out his hand, laughing.&nbsp; &ldquo;Is that a dream?&rdquo; said he, placing it close to my eyes.&nbsp; He had a rounded, muscular, and vigorous hand, as well as a long, strong arm.

&ldquo;Yes; though I touch it, it is a dream,&rdquo; said I, as I put it down from before my face.&nbsp; &ldquo;Sir, have you finished supper?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Yes, Jane.&rdquo;

I rang the bell and ordered away the tray.&nbsp; When we were again alone, I stirred the fire, and then took a low seat at my master&rsquo;s knee.

&ldquo;It is near midnight,&rdquo; I said.

&ldquo;Yes: but remember, Jane, you promised to wake with me the night before my wedding.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I did; and I will keep my promise, for an hour or two at least: I have no wish to go to bed.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Are all your arrangements complete?&rdquo;

&ldquo;All, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And on my part likewise,&rdquo; he returned, &ldquo;I have settled everything; and we shall leave Thornfield to-morrow, within half-an-hour after our return from church.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Very well, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;With what an extraordinary smile you uttered that word&mdash;&lsquo;very well,&rsquo; Jane!&nbsp; What a bright spot of colour you have on each cheek! and how strangely your eyes glitter!&nbsp; Are you well?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I believe I am.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Believe!&nbsp; What is the matter?&nbsp; Tell me what you feel.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I could not, sir: no words could tell you what I feel.&nbsp; I wish this present hour would never end: who knows with what fate the next may come charged?&rdquo;

&ldquo;This is hypochondria, Jane.&nbsp; You have been over-excited, or over-fatigued.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Do you, sir, feel calm and happy?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Calm?&mdash;no: but happy&mdash;to the heart&rsquo;s core.&rdquo;

I looked up at him to read the signs of bliss in his face: it was ardent and flushed.

&ldquo;Give me your confidence, Jane,&rdquo; he said: &ldquo;relieve your mind of any weight that oppresses it, by imparting it to me.&nbsp; What do you fear?&mdash;that I shall not prove a good husband?&rdquo;

&ldquo;It is the idea farthest from my thoughts.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Are you apprehensive of the new sphere you are about to enter?&mdash;of the new life into which you are passing?&rdquo;

&ldquo;No.&rdquo;

&ldquo;You puzzle me, Jane: your look and tone of sorrowful audacity perplex and pain me.&nbsp; I want an explanation.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Then, sir, listen.&nbsp; You were from home last night?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I was: I know that; and you hinted a while ago at something which had happened in my absence:&mdash;nothing, probably, of consequence; but, in short, it has disturbed you.&nbsp; Let me hear it.&nbsp; Mrs. Fairfax has said something, perhaps? or you have overheard the servants talk?&mdash;your sensitive self-respect has been wounded?&rdquo;

&ldquo;No, sir.&rdquo;&nbsp; It struck twelve&mdash;I waited till the time-piece had concluded its silver chime, and the clock its hoarse, vibrating stroke, and then I proceeded.

&ldquo;All day yesterday I was very busy, and very happy in my ceaseless bustle; for I am not, as you seem to think, troubled by any haunting fears about the new sphere, et cetera: I think it a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, because I love you.&nbsp; No, sir, don&rsquo;t caress me now&mdash;let me talk undisturbed.&nbsp; Yesterday I trusted well in Providence, and believed that events were working together for your good and mine: it was a fine day, if you recollect&mdash;the calmness of the air and sky forbade apprehensions respecting your safety or comfort on your journey.&nbsp; I walked a little while on the pavement after tea, thinking of you; and I beheld you in imagination so near me, I scarcely missed your actual presence.&nbsp; I thought of the life that lay before me&mdash;your life, sir&mdash;an existence more expansive and stirring than my own: as much more so as the depths of the sea to which the brook runs are than the shallows of its own strait channel.&nbsp; I wondered why moralists call this world a dreary wilderness: for me it blossomed like a rose.&nbsp; Just at sunset, the air turned cold and the sky cloudy: I went in, Sophie called me upstairs to look at my wedding-dress, which they had just brought; and under it in the box I found your present&mdash;the veil which, in your princely extravagance, you sent for from London: resolved, I suppose, since I would not have jewels, to cheat me into accepting something as costly.&nbsp; I smiled as I unfolded it, and devised how I would tease you about your aristocratic tastes, and your efforts to masque your plebeian bride in the attributes of a peeress.&nbsp; I thought how I would carry down to you the square of unembroidered blond I had myself prepared as a covering for my low-born head, and ask if that was not good enough for a woman who could bring her husband neither fortune, beauty, nor connections.&nbsp; I saw plainly how you would look; and heard your impetuous republican answers, and your haughty disavowal of any necessity on your part to augment your wealth, or elevate your standing, by marrying either a purse or a coronet.&rdquo;

&ldquo;How well you read me, you witch!&rdquo; interposed Mr. Rochester: &ldquo;but what did you find in the veil besides its embroidery?&nbsp; Did you find poison, or a dagger, that you look so mournful now?&rdquo;

&ldquo;No, no, sir; besides the delicacy and richness of the fabric, I found nothing save Fairfax Rochester&rsquo;s pride; and that did not scare me, because I am used to the sight of the demon.&nbsp; But, sir, as it grew dark, the wind rose: it blew yesterday evening, not as it blows now&mdash;wild and high&mdash;but &lsquo;with a sullen, moaning sound&rsquo; far more eerie.&nbsp; I wished you were at home.&nbsp; I came into this room, and the sight of the empty chair and fireless hearth chilled me.&nbsp; For some time after I went to bed, I could not sleep&mdash;a sense of anxious excitement distressed me.&nbsp; The gale still rising, seemed to my ear to muffle a mournful under-sound; whether in the house or abroad I could not at first tell, but it recurred, doubtful yet doleful at every lull; at last I made out it must be some dog howling at a distance.&nbsp; I was glad when it ceased.&nbsp; On sleeping, I continued in dreams the idea of a dark and gusty night.&nbsp; I continued also the wish to be with you, and experienced a strange, regretful consciousness of some barrier dividing us.&nbsp; During all my first sleep, I was following the windings of an unknown road; total obscurity environed me; rain pelted me; I was burdened with the charge of a little child: a very small creature, too young and feeble to walk, and which shivered in my cold arms, and wailed piteously in my ear.&nbsp; I thought, sir, that you were on the road a long way before me; and I strained every nerve to overtake you, and made effort on effort to utter your name and entreat you to stop&mdash;but my movements were fettered, and my voice still died away inarticulate; while you, I felt, withdrew farther and farther every moment.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And these dreams weigh on your spirits now, Jane, when I am close to you?&nbsp; Little nervous subject!&nbsp; Forget visionary woe, and think only of real happiness!&nbsp; You say you love me, Janet: yes&mdash;I will not forget that; and you cannot deny it.&nbsp; Those words did not die inarticulate on your lips.&nbsp; I heard them clear and soft: a thought too solemn perhaps, but sweet as music&mdash;&lsquo;I think it is a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, Edward, because I love you.&rsquo;&nbsp; Do you love me, Jane?&mdash;repeat it.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I do, sir&mdash;I do, with my whole heart.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Well,&rdquo; he said, after some minutes&rsquo; silence, &ldquo;it is strange; but that sentence has penetrated my breast painfully.&nbsp; Why?&nbsp; I think because you said it with such an earnest, religious energy, and because your upward gaze at me now is the very sublime of faith, truth, and devotion: it is too much as if some spirit were near me.&nbsp; Look wicked, Jane: as you know well how to look: coin one of your wild, shy, provoking smiles; tell me you hate me&mdash;tease me, vex me; do anything but move me: I would rather be incensed than saddened.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I will tease you and vex you to your heart&rsquo;s content, when I have finished my tale: but hear me to the end.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I thought, Jane, you had told me all.&nbsp; I thought I had found the source of your melancholy in a dream.&rdquo;

I shook my head.&nbsp; &ldquo;What! is there more?&nbsp; But I will not believe it to be anything important.&nbsp; I warn you of incredulity beforehand.&nbsp; Go on.&rdquo;

The disquietude of his air, the somewhat apprehensive impatience of his manner, surprised me: but I proceeded.

&ldquo;I dreamt another dream, sir: that Thornfield Hall was a dreary ruin, the retreat of bats and owls.&nbsp; I thought that of all the stately front nothing remained but a shell-like wall, very high and very fragile-looking.&nbsp; I wandered, on a moonlight night, through the grass-grown enclosure within: here I stumbled over a marble hearth, and there over a fallen fragment of cornice.&nbsp; Wrapped up in a shawl, I still carried the unknown little child: I might not lay it down anywhere, however tired were my arms&mdash;however much its weight impeded my progress, I must retain it.&nbsp; I heard the gallop of a horse at a distance on the road; I was sure it was you; and you were departing for many years and for a distant country.&nbsp; I climbed the thin wall with frantic perilous haste, eager to catch one glimpse of you from the top: the stones rolled from under my feet, the ivy branches I grasped gave way, the child clung round my neck in terror, and almost strangled me; at last I gained the summit.&nbsp; I saw you like a speck on a white track, lessening every moment.&nbsp; The blast blew so strong I could not stand.&nbsp; I sat down on the narrow ledge; I hushed the scared infant in my lap: you turned an angle of the road: I bent forward to take a last look; the wall crumbled; I was shaken; the child rolled from my knee, I lost my balance, fell, and woke.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Now, Jane, that is all.&rdquo;

&ldquo;All the preface, sir; the tale is yet to come.&nbsp; On waking, a gleam dazzled my eyes; I thought&mdash;Oh, it is daylight!&nbsp; But I was mistaken; it was only candlelight.&nbsp; Sophie, I supposed, had come in.&nbsp; There was a light in the dressing-table, and the door of the closet, where, before going to bed, I had hung my wedding-dress and veil, stood open; I heard a rustling there.&nbsp; I asked, &lsquo;Sophie, what are you doing?&rsquo;&nbsp; No one answered; but a form emerged from the closet; it took the light, held it aloft, and surveyed the garments pendent from the portmanteau.&nbsp; &lsquo;Sophie!&nbsp; Sophie!&rsquo;&nbsp; I again cried: and still it was silent.&nbsp; I had risen up in bed, I bent forward: first surprise, then bewilderment, came over me; and then my blood crept cold through my veins.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester, this was not Sophie, it was not Leah, it was not Mrs. Fairfax: it was not&mdash;no, I was sure of it, and am still&mdash;it was not even that strange woman, Grace Poole.&rdquo;

&ldquo;It must have been one of them,&rdquo; interrupted my master.

&ldquo;No, sir, I solemnly assure you to the contrary.&nbsp; The shape standing before me had never crossed my eyes within the precincts of Thornfield Hall before; the height, the contour were new to me.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Describe it, Jane.&rdquo;

&ldquo;It seemed, sir, a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back.&nbsp; I know not what dress she had on: it was white and straight; but whether gown, sheet, or shroud, I cannot tell.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Did you see her face?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Not at first.&nbsp; But presently she took my veil from its place; she held it up, gazed at it long, and then she threw it over her own head, and turned to the mirror.&nbsp; At that moment I saw the reflection of the visage and features quite distinctly in the dark oblong glass.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And how were they?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Fearful and ghastly to me&mdash;oh, sir, I never saw a face like it!&nbsp; It was a discoloured face&mdash;it was a savage face.&nbsp; I wish I could forget the roll of the red eyes and the fearful blackened inflation of the lineaments!&rdquo;

&ldquo;Ghosts are usually pale, Jane.&rdquo;

&ldquo;This, sir, was purple: the lips were swelled and dark; the brow furrowed: the black eyebrows widely raised over the bloodshot eyes.&nbsp; Shall I tell you of what it reminded me?&rdquo;

&ldquo;You may.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Of the foul German spectre&mdash;the Vampyre.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Ah!&mdash;what did it do?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Sir, it removed my veil from its gaunt head, rent it in two parts, and flinging both on the floor, trampled on them.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Afterwards?&rdquo;

&ldquo;It drew aside the window-curtain and looked out; perhaps it saw dawn approaching, for, taking the candle, it retreated to the door.&nbsp; Just at my bedside, the figure stopped: the fiery eyes glared upon me&mdash;she thrust up her candle close to my face, and extinguished it under my eyes.&nbsp; I was aware her lurid visage flamed over mine, and I lost consciousness: for the second time in my life&mdash;only the second time&mdash;I became insensible from terror.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Who was with you when you revived?&rdquo;

&ldquo;No one, sir, but the broad day.&nbsp; I rose, bathed my head and face in water, drank a long draught; felt that though enfeebled I was not ill, and determined that to none but you would I impart this vision.&nbsp; Now, sir, tell me who and what that woman was?&rdquo;

&ldquo;The creature of an over-stimulated brain; that is certain.&nbsp; I must be careful of you, my treasure: nerves like yours were not made for rough handling.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Sir, depend on it, my nerves were not in fault; the thing was real: the transaction actually took place.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And your previous dreams, were they real too?&nbsp; Is Thornfield Hall a ruin?&nbsp; Am I severed from you by insuperable obstacles?&nbsp; Am I leaving you without a tear&mdash;without a kiss&mdash;without a word?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Not yet.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Am I about to do it?&nbsp; Why, the day is already commenced which is to bind us indissolubly; and when we are once united, there shall be no recurrence of these mental terrors: I guarantee that.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Mental terrors, sir!&nbsp; I wish I could believe them to be only such: I wish it more now than ever; since even you cannot explain to me the mystery of that awful visitant.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And since I cannot do it, Jane, it must have been unreal.&rdquo;

&ldquo;But, sir, when I said so to myself on rising this morning, and when I looked round the room to gather courage and comfort from the cheerful aspect of each familiar object in full daylight, there&mdash;on the carpet&mdash;I saw what gave the distinct lie to my hypothesis,&mdash;the veil, torn from top to bottom in two halves!&rdquo;

I felt Mr. Rochester start and shudder; he hastily flung his arms round me.&nbsp; &ldquo;Thank God!&rdquo; he exclaimed, &ldquo;that if anything malignant did come near you last night, it was only the veil that was harmed.&nbsp; Oh, to think what might have happened!&rdquo;

He drew his breath short, and strained me so close to him, I could scarcely pant.&nbsp; After some minutes&rsquo; silence, he continued, cheerily&mdash;

&ldquo;Now, Janet, I&rsquo;ll explain to you all about it.&nbsp; It was half dream, half reality.&nbsp; A woman did, I doubt not, enter your room: and that woman was&mdash;must have been&mdash;Grace Poole.&nbsp; You call her a strange being yourself: from all you know, you have reason so to call her&mdash;what did she do to me? what to Mason?&nbsp; In a state between sleeping and waking, you noticed her entrance and her actions; but feverish, almost delirious as you were, you ascribed to her a goblin appearance different from her own: the long dishevelled hair, the swelled black face, the exaggerated stature, were figments of imagination; results of nightmare: the spiteful tearing of the veil was real: and it is like her.&nbsp; I see you would ask why I keep such a woman in my house: when we have been married a year and a day, I will tell you; but not now.&nbsp; Are you satisfied, Jane?&nbsp; Do you accept my solution of the mystery?&rdquo;

I reflected, and in truth it appeared to me the only possible one: satisfied I was not, but to please him I endeavoured to appear so&mdash;relieved, I certainly did feel; so I answered him with a contented smile.&nbsp; And now, as it was long past one, I prepared to leave him.

&ldquo;Does not Sophie sleep with Ad&egrave;le in the nursery?&rdquo; he asked, as I lit my candle.

&ldquo;Yes, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And there is room enough in Ad&egrave;le&rsquo;s little bed for you.&nbsp; You must share it with her to-night, Jane: it is no wonder that the incident you have related should make you nervous, and I would rather you did not sleep alone: promise me to go to the nursery.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I shall be very glad to do so, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And fasten the door securely on the inside.&nbsp; Wake Sophie when you go upstairs, under pretence of requesting her to rouse you in good time to-morrow; for you must be dressed and have finished breakfast before eight.&nbsp; And now, no more sombre thoughts: chase dull care away, Janet.&nbsp; Don&rsquo;t you hear to what soft whispers the wind has fallen? and there is no more beating of rain against the window-panes: look here&rdquo; (he lifted up the curtain)&mdash;&ldquo;it is a lovely night!&rdquo;

It was.&nbsp; Half heaven was pure and stainless: the clouds, now trooping before the wind, which had shifted to the west, were filing off eastward in long, silvered columns.&nbsp; The moon shone peacefully.

&ldquo;Well,&rdquo; said Mr. Rochester, gazing inquiringly into my eyes, &ldquo;how is my Janet now?&rdquo;

&ldquo;The night is serene, sir; and so am I.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And you will not dream of separation and sorrow to-night; but of happy love and blissful union.&rdquo;

This prediction was but half fulfilled: I did not indeed dream of sorrow, but as little did I dream of joy; for I never slept at all.&nbsp; With little Ad&egrave;le in my arms, I watched the slumber of childhood&mdash;so tranquil, so passionless, so innocent&mdash;and waited for the coming day: all my life was awake and astir in my frame: and as soon as the sun rose I rose too.&nbsp; I remember Ad&egrave;le clung to me as I left her: I remember I kissed her as I loosened her little hands from my neck; and I cried over her with strange emotion, and quitted her because I feared my sobs would break her still sound repose.&nbsp; She seemed the emblem of my past life; and here I was now to array myself to meet, the dread, but adored, type of my unknown future day.

CHAPTER XXVI

Sophie came at seven to dress me: she was very long indeed in accomplishing her task; so long that Mr. Rochester, grown, I suppose, impatient of my delay, sent up to ask why I did not come.&nbsp; She was just fastening my veil (the plain square of blond after all) to my hair with a brooch; I hurried from under her hands as soon as I could.

&ldquo;Stop!&rdquo; she cried in French.&nbsp; &ldquo;Look at yourself in the mirror: you have not taken one peep.&rdquo;

So I turned at the door: I saw a robed and veiled figure, so unlike my usual self that it seemed almost the image of a stranger.&nbsp; &ldquo;Jane!&rdquo; called a voice, and I hastened down.&nbsp; I was received at the foot of the stairs by Mr. Rochester.

&ldquo;Lingerer!&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;my brain is on fire with impatience, and you tarry so long!&rdquo;

He took me into the dining-room, surveyed me keenly all over, pronounced me &ldquo;fair as a lily, and not only the pride of his life, but the desire of his eyes,&rdquo; and then telling me he would give me but ten minutes to eat some breakfast, he rang the bell.&nbsp; One of his lately hired servants, a footman, answered it.

&ldquo;Is John getting the carriage ready?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Yes, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Is the luggage brought down?&rdquo;

&ldquo;They are bringing it down, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Go you to the church: see if Mr. Wood (the clergyman) and the clerk are there: return and tell me.&rdquo;

The church, as the reader knows, was but just beyond the gates; the footman soon returned.

&ldquo;Mr. Wood is in the vestry, sir, putting on his surplice.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And the carriage?&rdquo;

&ldquo;The horses are harnessing.&rdquo;

&ldquo;We shall not want it to go to church; but it must be ready the moment we return: all the boxes and luggage arranged and strapped on, and the coachman in his seat.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Yes, sir.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Jane, are you ready?&rdquo;

I rose.&nbsp; There were no groomsmen, no bridesmaids, no relatives to wait for or marshal: none but Mr. Rochester and I.&nbsp; Mrs. Fairfax stood in the hall as we passed.&nbsp;&nbsp; I would fain have spoken to her, but my hand was held by a grasp of iron: I was hurried along by a stride I could hardly follow; and to look at Mr. Rochester&rsquo;s face was to feel that not a second of delay would be tolerated for any purpose.&nbsp; I wonder what other bridegroom ever looked as he did&mdash;so bent up to a purpose, so grimly resolute: or who, under such steadfast brows, ever revealed such flaming and flashing eyes.

I know not whether the day was fair or foul; in descending the drive, I gazed neither on sky nor earth: my heart was with my eyes; and both seemed migrated into Mr. Rochester&rsquo;s frame.&nbsp; I wanted to see the invisible thing on which, as we went along, he appeared to fasten a glance fierce and fell.&nbsp; I wanted to feel the thoughts whose force he seemed breasting and resisting.

At the churchyard wicket he stopped: he discovered I was quite out of breath.&nbsp; &ldquo;Am I cruel in my love?&rdquo; he said.&nbsp; &ldquo;Delay an instant: lean on me, Jane.&rdquo;

And now I can recall the picture of the grey old house of God rising calm before me, of a rook wheeling round the steeple, of a ruddy morning sky beyond.&nbsp; I remember something, too, of the green grave-mounds; and I have not forgotten, either, two figures of strangers straying amongst the low hillocks and reading the mementoes graven on the few mossy head-stones.&nbsp; I noticed them, because, as they saw us, they passed round to the back of the church; and I doubted not they were going to enter by the side-aisle door and witness the ceremony.&nbsp; By Mr. Rochester they were not observed; he was earnestly looking at my face from which the blood had, I daresay, momentarily fled: for I felt my forehead dewy, and my cheeks and lips cold.&nbsp; When I rallied, which I soon did, he walked gently with me up the path to the porch.

We entered the quiet and humble temple; the priest waited in his white surplice at the lowly altar, the clerk beside him.&nbsp; All was still: two shadows only moved in a remote corner.&nbsp; My conjecture had been correct: the strangers had slipped in before us, and they now stood by the vault of the Rochesters, their backs towards us, viewing through the rails the old time-stained marble tomb, where a kneeling angel guarded the remains of Damer de Rochester, slain at Marston Moor in the time of the civil wars, and of Elizabeth, his wife.

Our place was taken at the communion rails.&nbsp; Hearing a cautious step behind me, I glanced over my shoulder: one of the strangers&mdash;a gentleman, evidently&mdash;was advancing up the chancel.&nbsp; The service began.&nbsp; The explanation of the intent of matrimony was gone through; and then the clergyman came a step further forward, and, bending slightly towards Mr. Rochester, went on.

&ldquo;I require and charge you both (as ye will answer at the dreadful day of judgment, when the secrets of all hearts shall be disclosed), that if either of you know any impediment why ye may not lawfully be joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it; for be ye well assured that so many as are coupled together otherwise than God&rsquo;s Word doth allow, are not joined together by God, neither is their matrimony lawful.&rdquo;

He paused, as the custom is.&nbsp; When is the pause after that sentence ever broken by reply?&nbsp; Not, perhaps, once in a hundred years.&nbsp; And the clergyman, who had not lifted his eyes from his book, and had held his breath but for a moment, was proceeding: his hand was already stretched towards Mr. Rochester, as his lips unclosed to ask, &ldquo;Wilt thou have this woman for thy wedded wife?&rdquo;&mdash;when a distinct and near voice said&mdash;

&ldquo;The marriage cannot go on: I declare the existence of an impediment.&rdquo;

The clergyman looked up at the speaker and stood mute; the clerk did the same; Mr. Rochester moved slightly, as if an earthquake had rolled under his feet: taking a firmer footing, and not turning his head or eyes, he said, &ldquo;Proceed.&rdquo;

Profound silence fell when he had uttered that word, with deep but low intonation.&nbsp; Presently Mr. Wood said&mdash;

&ldquo;I cannot proceed without some investigation into what has been asserted, and evidence of its truth or falsehood.&rdquo;

&ldquo;The ceremony is quite broken off,&rdquo; subjoined the voice behind us.&nbsp; &ldquo;I am in a condition to prove my allegation: an insuperable impediment to this marriage exists.&rdquo;

Mr. Rochester heard, but heeded not: he stood stubborn and rigid, making no movement but to possess himself of my hand.&nbsp; What a hot and strong grasp he had! and how like quarried marble was his pale, firm, massive front at this moment!&nbsp; How his eye shone, still watchful, and yet wild beneath!

Mr. Wood seemed at a loss.&nbsp; &ldquo;What is the nature of the impediment?&rdquo; he asked.&nbsp; &ldquo;Perhaps it may be got over&mdash;explained away?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Hardly,&rdquo; was the answer.&nbsp; &ldquo;I have called it insuperable, and I speak advisedly.&rdquo;

The speaker came forward and leaned on the rails.&nbsp; He continued, uttering each word distinctly, calmly, steadily, but not loudly&mdash;

&ldquo;It simply consists in the existence of a previous marriage.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester has a wife now living.&rdquo;

My nerves vibrated to those low-spoken words as they had never vibrated to thunder&mdash;my blood felt their subtle violence as it had never felt frost or fire; but I was collected, and in no danger of swooning.&nbsp; I looked at Mr. Rochester: I made him look at me.&nbsp; His whole face was colourless rock: his eye was both spark and flint.&nbsp; He disavowed nothing: he seemed as if he would defy all things.&nbsp; Without speaking, without smiling, without seeming to recognise in me a human being, he only twined my waist with his arm and riveted me to his side.

&ldquo;Who are you?&rdquo; he asked of the intruder.

&ldquo;My name is Briggs, a solicitor of --- Street, London.&rdquo;

&ldquo;And you would thrust on me a wife?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I would remind you of your lady&rsquo;s existence, sir, which the law recognises, if you do not.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Favour me with an account of her&mdash;with her name, her parentage, her place of abode.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Certainly.&rdquo;&nbsp; Mr. Briggs calmly took a paper from his pocket, and read out in a sort of official, nasal voice:&mdash;

&ldquo;&lsquo;I affirm and can prove that on the 20th of October A.D. --- (a date of fifteen years back), Edward Fairfax Rochester, of Thornfield Hall, in the county of ---, and of Ferndean Manor, in ---shire, England, was married to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason, daughter of Jonas Mason, merchant, and of Antoinetta his wife, a Creole, at --- church, Spanish Town, Jamaica.&nbsp; The record of the marriage will be found in the register of that church&mdash;a copy of it is now in my possession.&nbsp; Signed, Richard Mason.&rsquo;&rdquo;

&ldquo;That&mdash;if a genuine document&mdash;may prove I have been married, but it does not prove that the woman mentioned therein as my wife is still living.&rdquo;

&ldquo;She was living three months ago,&rdquo; returned the lawyer.

&ldquo;How do you know?&rdquo;

&ldquo;I have a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will scarcely controvert.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Produce him&mdash;or go to hell.&rdquo;

&ldquo;I will produce him first&mdash;he is on the spot.&nbsp; Mr. Mason, have the goodness to step forward.&rdquo;

Mr. Rochester, on hearing the name, set his teeth; he experienced, too, a sort of strong convulsive quiver; near to him as I was, I felt the spasmodic movement of fury or despair run through his frame.&nbsp; The second stranger, who had hitherto lingered in the background, now drew near; a pale face looked over the solicitor&rsquo;s shoulder&mdash;yes, it was Mason himself.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester turned and glared at him.&nbsp; His eye, as I have often said, was a black eye: it had now a tawny, nay, a bloody light in its gloom; and his face flushed&mdash;olive cheek and hueless forehead received a glow as from spreading, ascending heart-fire: and he stirred, lifted his strong arm&mdash;he could have struck Mason, dashed him on the church-floor, shocked by ruthless blow the breath from his body&mdash;but Mason shrank away, and cried faintly, &ldquo;Good God!&rdquo;&nbsp; Contempt fell cool on Mr. Rochester&mdash;his passion died as if a blight had shrivelled it up: he only asked&mdash;&ldquo;What have you to say?&rdquo;

An inaudible reply escaped Mason&rsquo;s white lips.

&ldquo;The devil is in it if you cannot answer distinctly.&nbsp; I again demand, what have you to say?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Sir&mdash;sir,&rdquo; interrupted the clergyman, &ldquo;do not forget you are in a sacred place.&rdquo;&nbsp; Then addressing Mason, he inquired gently, &ldquo;Are you aware, sir, whether or not this gentleman&rsquo;s wife is still living?&rdquo;

&ldquo;Courage,&rdquo; urged the lawyer,&mdash;&ldquo;speak out.&rdquo;

&ldquo;She is now living at Thornfield Hall,&rdquo; said Mason, in more articulate tones: &ldquo;I saw her there last April.&nbsp; I am her brother.&rdquo;

&ldquo;At Thornfield Hall!&rdquo; ejaculated the clergyman.&nbsp; &ldquo;Impossible!&nbsp; I am an old resident in this neighbourhood, sir, and I never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at Thornfield Hall.&rdquo;

I saw a grim smile contort Mr. Rochester&rsquo;s lips, and he muttered&mdash;

&ldquo;No, by God!&nbsp; I took care that none should hear of it&mdash;or of her under that name.&rdquo;&nbsp; He mused&mdash;for ten minutes he held counsel with himself: he formed his resolve, and announced it&mdash;

&ldquo;Enough! all shall bolt out at once, like the bullet from the barrel.&nbsp; Wood, close your book and take off your surplice; John Green (to the clerk), leave the church: there will be no wedding to-day.&rdquo;&nbsp; The man obeyed.

Mr. Rochester continued, hardily and recklessly: &ldquo;Bigamy is an ugly word!&mdash;I meant, however, to be a bigamist; but fate has out-manoeuvred me, or Providence has checked me,&mdash;perhaps the last.&nbsp; I am little better than a devil at this moment; and, as my pastor there would tell me, deserve no doubt the sternest judgments of God, even to the quenchless fire and deathless worm.&nbsp; Gentlemen, my plan is broken up:&mdash;what this lawyer and his client say is true: I have been married, and the woman to whom I was married lives!&nbsp; You say you never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at the house up yonder, Wood; but I daresay you have many a time inclined your ear to gossip about the mysterious lunatic kept there under watch and ward.&nbsp; Some have whispered to you that she is my bastard half-sister: some, my cast-off mistress.&nbsp; I now inform you that she is my wife, whom I married fifteen years ago,&mdash;Bertha Mason by name; sister of this resolute personage, who is now, with his quivering limbs and white cheeks, showing you what a stout heart men may bear.&nbsp; Cheer up, Dick!&mdash;never fear me!&mdash;I&rsquo;d almost as soon strike a woman as you.&nbsp; Bertha Mason is mad; and she came of a mad family; idiots and maniacs through three generations!&nbsp; Her mother, the Creole, was both a madwoman and a drunkard!&mdash;as I found out after I had wed the daughter: for they were silent on family secrets before.&nbsp; Bertha, like a dutiful child, copied her parent in both points.&nbsp; I had a charming partner&mdash;pure, wise, modest: you can fancy I was a happy man.&nbsp; I went through rich scenes!&nbsp; Oh! my experience has been heavenly, if you only knew it!&nbsp; But I owe you no further explanation.&nbsp; Briggs, Wood, Mason, I invite you all to come up to the house and visit Mrs. Poole&rsquo;s patient, and my wife!&nbsp; You shall see what sort of a being I was cheated into espousing, and judge whether or not I had a right to break the compact, and seek sympathy with something at least human.&nbsp; This girl,&rdquo; he continued, looking at me, &ldquo;knew no more than you, Wood, of the disgusting secret: she thought all was fair and legal and never dreamt she was going to be entrapped into a feigned union with a defrauded wretch, already bound to a bad, mad, and embruted partner!&nbsp; Come all of you&mdash;follow!&rdquo;

Still holding me fast, he left the church: the three gentlemen came after.&nbsp; At the front door of the hall we found the carriage.

&ldquo;Take it back to the coach-house, John,&rdquo; said Mr. Rochester coolly; &ldquo;it will not be wanted to-day.&rdquo;

At our entrance, Mrs. Fairfax, Ad&egrave;le, Sophie, Leah, advanced to meet and greet us.

&ldquo;To the right-about&mdash;every soul!&rdquo; cried the master; &ldquo;away with your congratulations!&nbsp; Who wants them?&nbsp; Not I!&mdash;they are fifteen years too late!&rdquo;

He passed on and ascended the stairs, still holding my hand, and still beckoning the gentlemen to follow him, which they did.&nbsp; We mounted the first staircase, passed up the gallery, proceeded to the third storey: the low, black door, opened by Mr. Rochester&rsquo;s master-key, admitted us to the tapestried room, with its great bed and its pictorial cabinet.

&ldquo;You know this place, Mason,&rdquo; said our guide; &ldquo;she bit and stabbed you here.&rdquo;

He lifted the hangings from the wall, uncovering the second door: this, too, he opened.&nbsp; In a room without a window, there burnt a fire guarded by a high and strong fender, and a lamp suspended from the ceiling by a chain.&nbsp; Grace Poole bent over the fire, apparently cooking something in a saucepan.&nbsp; In the deep shade, at the farther end of the room, a figure ran backwards and forwards.&nbsp; What it was, whether beast or human being, one could not, at first sight, tell: it grovelled, seemingly, on all fours; it snatched and growled like some strange wild animal: but it was covered with clothing, and a quantity of dark, grizzled hair, wild as a mane, hid its head and face.

&ldquo;Good-morrow, Mrs. Poole!&rdquo; said Mr. Rochester.&nbsp; &ldquo;How are you? and how is your charge to-day?&rdquo;

&ldquo;We&rsquo;re tolerable, sir, I thank you,&rdquo; replied Grace, lifting the boiling mess carefully on to the hob: &ldquo;rather snappish, but not &lsquo;rageous.&rdquo;

A fierce cry seemed to give the lie to her favourable report: the clothed hyena rose up, and stood tall on its hind-feet.

&ldquo;Ah! sir, she sees you!&rdquo; exclaimed Grace: &ldquo;you&rsquo;d better not stay.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Only a few moments, Grace: you must allow me a few moments.&rdquo;

&ldquo;Take care then, sir!&mdash;for God&rsquo;s sake, take care!&rdquo;

The maniac bellowed: she parted her shaggy locks from her visage, and gazed wildly at her visitors.&nbsp; I recognised well that purple face,&mdash;those bloated features.&nbsp; Mrs. Poole advanced.

&ldquo;Keep out of the way,&rdquo; said Mr. Rochester, thrusting her aside: &ldquo;she has no knife now, I suppose, and I&rsquo;m on my guard.&rdquo;

&ldquo;One never knows what she has, sir: she is so cunning: it is not in mortal discretion to fathom her craft.&rdquo;

&ldquo;We had better leave her,&rdquo; whispered Mason.

&ldquo;Go to the devil!&rdquo; was his brother-in-law&rsquo;s recommendation.

&ldquo;&lsquo;Ware!&rdquo; cried Grace.&nbsp; The three gentlemen retreated simultaneously.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester flung me behind him: the lunatic sprang and grappled his throat viciously, and laid her teeth to his cheek: they struggled.&nbsp; She was a big woman, in stature almost equalling her husband, and corpulent besides: she showed virile force in the contest&mdash;more than once she almost throttled him, athletic as he was.&nbsp; He could have settled her with a well-planted blow; but he would not strike: he would only wrestle.&nbsp; At last he mastered her arms; Grace Poole gave him a cord, and he pinioned them behind her: with more rope, which was at hand, he bound her to a chair.&nbsp; The operation was performed amidst the fiercest yells and the most convulsive plunges.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester then turned to the spectators: he looked at them with a smile both acrid and desolate.

&ldquo;That is my wife,&rdquo; said he.&nbsp; &ldquo;Such is the sole conjugal embrace I am ever to know&mdash;such are the endearments which are to solace my leisure hours!&nbsp; And this is what I wished to have&rdquo; (laying his hand on my shoulder): &ldquo;this young girl, who stands so grave and quiet at the mouth of hell, looking collectedly at the gambols of a demon, I wanted her just as a change after that fierce ragout.&nbsp; Wood and Briggs, look at the difference!&nbsp; Compare these clear eyes with the red balls yonder&mdash;this face with that mask&mdash;this form with that bulk; then judge me, priest of the gospel and man of the law, and remember with what judgment ye judge ye shall be judged!&nbsp; Off with you now.&nbsp; I must shut up my prize.&rdquo;

We all withdrew.&nbsp; Mr. Rochester stayed a moment behind us, to give some further order to Grace Poole.&nbsp; The solicitor addressed me as he descended the stair.

&ldquo;You, madam,&rdquo; said he, &ldquo;are cleared from all blame: your uncle will be glad to hear it&mdash;if, indeed, he should be still living&mdash;when Mr. Mason returns to Madeira.&rdquo;

&ldquo;My uncle!&nbsp; What of him?&nbsp; Do you know him?&rdquo;
